advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>NorthStar brochure - Page 2 <b>EXPANSION OPTIONS</b><br><br> <b>HRAM.64</b> - High Speed 64Kb Dynamic RAM memory board with parity (up to a total of six)<br> <b>HSIO.4</b> - Four Serial Port Expansion Board (RS-232C or Current Loop).<br> <b>FPB</b> - Floating Point Arithmetic Board.<br> <b>ADC-2D</b> - Two additionaI 5 1/4 inch Double capacity floppy disk drives incorporated within a cabinet (360 Kb total capacity).<br> <b>ADC-2Q</b> - Two additionaI 5 1/4 inch Quad capacity floppy disk drives incorporated within a cabinet (720 Kb total capacity).<br> <b>HDS-5</b> - 5 1/4 inch Winchester Hard Disk 5 Mb formatted capacity.<br> <b>HDS-18</b> - 14 inch Winchester Hard Disk 18 Mb formatted capacity.<br> <b>Tape Backup</b> - 13.4 Mb Tape Backup system for HDS-18 or HDS-5.<br> <b>CRT</b> - Hazeltine 1420/Soroc 120. (Other software drivers available.)<br> <b>Printer</b> - 35 or 55 cps letter quality printer. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gordon Dyer</b> from England </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60 to show that the it is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really working ? ;-)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TTX 80 FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"computing against wasted time"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT JULY 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (FEB. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Educatel advert for their correspondance courses using the Microlab system.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french advert dated may 1980, shows the first model sold in France. It was called Victor Lambda and the company name was Lambda Systemes. This model was nothing more than an Interact computer, sold with an english documentation and a NTSC television !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a promotional picture for the Channel F System II.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is nearly a stupid scan ! <br><br> The young boy says : ''In 1984, my father bought me a MO-5" <br> And on his desk is a 1998 calendar... <br><br> They meant that if you bought the MO-5 then (the advert is from 1984), you would be rich and clever 14 years later (in 1998). Ha ha ha !! <br><br> It's funny to see how they tried to represent an office and a town of 1998. I really love this one ! </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Doctors, it gonna cure your work" <br><br> "ITT 3030, the absolute intelligence"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You know about computers. In fact, you probably own one now. One that you might be thinking of expanding. We have a better idea. Take a giant step into the personal computing future with an amazing, new C4P from Ohio Scientific...<br><br> ...The C4P is an outstanding premium computer - years ahead of the market. We know because there's nothing quite like it for the price, anywhere. And probably won't be for a very long time.</font> <br><br> About the DISPLAY paragraph:<font color="#666666"><br> "256 x 512 effective graphic points"<br><br></font> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> rectifies:<font color="#666666"><br> The C4P did NOT have a 256x512 graphics mode! If it had, that would have been amazing for the price way back then. Instead, it had a 32x64 character display and claimed that because each character was made up of a 8x8 grid that that was supposed to count as 256x512 graphics. Even given that they used an extended 8 bit character set that included special line and shape characters, you were NEVER able to address indivual pixels!</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US BROCHURE (RECTO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Chris Collman for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROF80 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert from Pentasonic stores chain.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 2 <br><br> "The domestic computer, business class"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1976 XMAS CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>This guy is so good as running his budget that he has become rich and bought himself a TO-7/70 ! Or did he get rich since he bought its TO-7/70 ? Anyway he is now smoking cigars and reads stock market newspapers... great</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Hyperion is a true portable weighting in at only 18 pounds. It is light on the eyes with its European amber screen and styling. But heavy on performances with many standard features which are expensive necessities for other personal computers. And all for a price that's less that you'd expect...</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> Z-2D ADVERT (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Z-2D 1977 price list:<br><br> - Kit version with 1 F.D. drive: <b>$1495</b><br> - Assembled version: <b>$2095</b><br> - Additional F.D. drive: <b>$495</b> </blockquote>

computer.description:
The Robotron A-5105 was intended to be used in former Eastern Germany schools where it should replace the outdated KC line of computers. Therefore, it was also called BIC which stands for "Bildungscomputer" ("educational computer")..
Up to 16 computers could be linked into a network which was comprised of one teacher computer and several pupil systems. Each station could access the printers and plotters.
A monochrome monitor was attached to the case but one could also connect a colour RGB monitor or a TV set.
The network software was called BICLAN. The machine ran SCPX, a special version of the CP/M operating system. The RBASIC interpreter was also in ROM. _______________________
computer.keyboard: Typewriter style, 69 keys with 5 function keys and arrow keys
computer.name: A5105
computer.ports: Tape drive2 joysticksZ80 bus connector2 parallel ports2 serial portsaudio stereoRGB, TV aerialLocal net (500 Kbit/sec, 100 m, 16 stations)
computer.ram: 64 KB (48 KB available with RBASIC) up to 128 KB
